title: Treasurer asked to stand up for borrowers
text:
“The best interests duty is the number one obligation for the government out of the Productivity Commission inquiry report, the royal commission and the PC superannuation report.”

Mr Harris, who retired from the government's Productivity Commission last year, said the best interests duty should apply consistently to brokers, bankers, superannuation fund trustees and financial advisers.

He said trailing commissions paid by banks to mortgage brokers – which the Morrison government backed down on axing before the election – created an incentive for the broker to keep the borrower with the existing lender.

A strong best interest duty would counteract the commission incentive, he said.

“Brokers are paid these trailing commissions and if someone is refinancing they go first to the existing loan provider, but there could be a better deal out there,” he said.

“The best interest duty will counteract the incentive created by the trailing commission which we are yet to see the government eliminate.”

New borrowers are often offered discount home loan rates, typically about half a percentage point lower than those paid by existing home loan borrowers.

Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman Rod Sims has said the gap suggested the banks were disrespecting their "loyal customers" and that the longer that a customer stayed with a bank "the more out-of-kilter it seems to become".

He wants to conduct a new mortgage pricing probe, which Treasurer Josh Frydenberg will formally consider once there is an official request from the ACCC.

Mortgage brokers arrange about 60 per cent of new mortgages.

Mr Frydenberg in August released exposure draft legislation incorporating a best interests duty and banning bonus commissions for the nation's 17,000 mortgage brokers.

Mark Hewitt, general manager at mortgage broking group Australian Finance Group, said he agreed the existing “not unsuitable” test for brokers was not strong enough and should be replaced by a best interests duty.

“But there are a number of factors around what is the best loan and it’s not always just the cheapest price,” Mr Hewitt said.

“Variable rates change between lenders, there are differences in the amount of time to approve a loan, risk appetite of the client and some clients have personal biases on particular lenders based on past experiences.”

The AFG wants the Australian Securities and Investments Commission to provide regulatory guidance after the legislation is approved by Parliament.

The industry is pushing for the best interest duty to apply at the point when the mortgage broker assists the customer take out the loan or refinance, not on an ongoing basis.

This reflects that people’s circumstances can change after they take out a loan, such as losing a job or suffering from ill health that reduces their income,and that lenders regularly change their loan conditions, pricing and product offers.

Consumer advocates are pushing the government to extend the proposed laws for brokers to other products such as bank accounts and mortgage insurance.

The industry wants the best interests test limited to its primary business of home loans, rather than extended to additional products such as insurance and credit cards.
description: Peter Harris, who retired as Productivity Commission chairman last year, says he favours introducing a stern best interest duty for bankers and mortgage brokers.
